{{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Solent Arena | nickname = | logo_image = Solent Arena Logo, Sep 2013.jpg | image = | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Fareham]], [[Hampshire]], [[England]] | coordinates = {{Coord|50|51|43.15|N|1|10|10.99|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 2013 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Salmiakki CIC | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = British Rink Hockey Association | seating_capacity = | dimensions = | website = {{URL|solent-arena.co.uk}} }}
'''Solent Arena''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|oʊ|l|ən|t}} {{respell|SOH|lənt}}) is an [[indoor arena]], in [[Fareham]], [[Hampshire]]. It is located alongside [[River Wallington]] by the [[M27 motorway]].
==History== The Solent Arena project was launched by Salmiakki CIC, a non-profit community sports organisation, in July 2012 with a view to build a purpose-built arena for non-mainstream and disabled sports on the English south coast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/news/business/local-business/rink-is-aimed-at-encouraging-more-people-to-try-sport-1-4881190 |title=Rink is aimed at encouraging more people to try sport |publisher=Portsmouth News |accessdate=29 September 2013}}</ref> Location search included a wide area along the M27 corridor from [[Portsmouth]] to [[Southampton]]. The [[Fareham (borough)|Fareham Borough Council]] was keen to attract the stadium into the borough due to the documented shortfall<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/news/sports-rink-would-be-one-of-five-of-its-kind-in-the-uk-1-4702618 |title=Sports rink would be one of five of its kind in the UK |publisher=Portsmouth News |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> in indoor sports provision in the area and agreed to finance the project with a 50% capital cost contribution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/life/specialist-rink-will-bring-cinderella-sports-to-the-fore-1-4930501 |title=Specialist rink will bring Cinderella sports to the fore |publisher=Portsmouth News |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/news/10280835.Fareham_rollerskate_rink_to_open/ |title=Fareham rollerskate rink to open |publisher=Southern Daily Echo |accessdate=29 September 2013}}</ref> [[Inline hockey]] was first played in the building in July 2013 by members of the Fareham Wildcats Roller Hockey Club, although the building was still unfinished.
==Sporting events== The main tenant of Solent Arena is the British Rink Hockey Association, Britain's oldest inline hockey league founded in 1983.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brha.co |title=British Rink Hockey Association |publisher=BRHA |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> BRHA team training and game slots take up approximately half of the arena's operational hours.
The arena is also home to Lemon Hockey tournaments<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lemonhockey.wix.com/the-championships |title=The Championships |publisher=Lemon Hockey |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> and there was a Guinness Book of World Records attempt at the longest inline hockey game in the world on 26–27 October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solent-arena.co.uk/worlds-longest-inline-hockey-game/ |title=World's Longest Inline Hockey Game |publisher=Solent Arena |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> In addition to inline hockey, the arena is home to [[floorball]], [[box lacrosse]] and [[roller derby]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solent-arena.co.uk/ |title=Solent Arena |publisher=Solent Arena |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref>
==Transport== Solent Arena is well served by the major road and rail networks. The [[M27 motorway]] passes just a few hundred metres from the arena, and is the main traffic [[Arterial road|artery]] into and out of the arena. It provides easy access to both [[Portsmouth]] and [[Southampton]], and from there to [[London]] via the [[M3 motorway (Great Britain)|M3]] and [[A3 road|A3(M)]].
The [[A27 road|A27]] was the original route along the south coast before the building of the M27, and runs from [[Brighton]] to [[Southampton]], passing through between the arena and Fareham Town Centre. The [[A32 road|A32]] gives access to [[Gosport]] and [[Wickham, Hampshire|Wickham]], and then through the picturesque [[River Meon|Meon Valley]] to [[Alton, Hampshire|Alton]].
[[Fareham railway station]] is on the [[West Coastway Line]], with regular services to [[Portsmouth]], [[Southampton]], [[Cardiff]] and [[London]].
Bus transport is provided by [[First Hampshire & Dorset]], which runs nearly all bus routes in the area.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstgroup.com/ukbus/hampshire/about_us/md_message/ |title=First Group Bus Services |publisher=FirstGroup plc |accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> There are two bus stops within a couple of minutes walk from the arena on Broadcut and North Wallington.
The onsite parking facility is partly shared with the Fareham Industrial Estate, essentially being the open air surface parking surrounding the eastern flank of Solent Arena. There is disabled parking available onsite, at the main car park nearest to the arena entrance. Car parking at the arena is free of charge to arena visitors.
{{Clear}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Solent Arena}} *[http://www.solent-arena.co.uk/ Official website]

revision.text:
[[File:Wood and carbon fibers tennis rackets.jpg|thumb|right|A [[tennis racket]] made of an advanced material such as [[carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer|carbon fibre reinforced plastic]] can have a larger head than a traditional racket made of wood.]] '''Sports engineering''' is a fast growing field of engineering which encompasses the design and production of [[sports equipment]] and [[sports venue|facilities]], performance measurement and athletic feedback systems, and the study of [[kinematics]], [[Dynamics (mechanics)|dynamics]] and [[biomechanics]] as they pertain to sport. The field overlaps other fields of science and engineering, including [[physics]], [[mechanical engineering]], [[electrical engineering]], and [[materials science]], and many practitioners hold degrees in those fields rather than in sports engineering specifically. While sports engineering is not a well known field among pre-college students, professional societies are working to change that.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sportsengineering.org/|title=International Sports Engineering Association|website=International Sports Engineering Association|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref><ref>{{citation |title=High Tech Hot Shots: Careers in Sports Engineering |author=Celeste Baine |publisher=National Society of Professional Engineers |year=2004 |isbn=9780915409235}}</ref> Study programs in sports engineering and technology at either the undergraduate or graduate level are now offered at a number of universities.
A sports engineering congress is biannually held, hosted by the [http://sportsengineering.org/ International Sports Engineering Association], termed 'The Engineering of Sport'. This conference brings world leading researchers, sports professionals and industry organizations together to celebrate the profession, showcasing new innovations in both research, and industry. The [http://www.isea2018.com.au/ next congress] will be hosted in March 26–29 in Brisbane, Australia.<ref>{{cite web|first1=ISEA|title=The Engineering of Sport|url=http://www.isea2018.com.au/}}</ref>
== Study programs in sports engineering == * [[Loughborough University]] (UK)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lboro.ac.uk/departments/ssehs/|title=School of Sport, Exercise and Health Sciences {{!}} Loughborough University|website=www.lboro.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * [https://www.shu.ac.uk/research/specialisms/centre-for-sports-engineering-research Centre for Sports Engineering Research (CSER) - Sheffield Hallam University] (UK)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.shu.ac.uk/research/specialisms/centre-for-sports-engineering-research|title=Centre for Sports Engineering Research {{!}} Sheffield Hallam University|website=www.shu.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * [[Delft University of Technology|TU Delft]] (Netherlands)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sportsengineering.tudelft.nl/|title=TU Delft Sports Engineering Institute {{!}} Sports Engineering Institute TU Delft - Home|website=sportsengineering.tudelft.nl|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * [[Griffith University]] (Australia)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.griffith.edu.au/engineering-information-technology/centre-wireless-monitoring-applications/research/sport-and-biomedical-program|title=Sport and Biomedical Program|website=www.griffith.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * [[University of Adelaide]] (Australia)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.adelaide.edu.au/degree-finder/beng_besportsen.html|title=Bachelor of Engineering (Honours)(Mechanical and Sports)|website=www.adelaide.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-04-06}}</ref> * [[Chemnitz University of Technology|TU Chemnitz]] (Germany) (undergraduate)<ref>{{Cite International Office {{!}} TU Chemnitz|last=IUZ|first=Admin|website=www.tu-chemnitz.de|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * TU Chemnitz (Germany) (graduate)<ref>{{Cite International Office {{!}} TU Chemnitz|last=IUZ|first=Admin|website=www.tu-chemnitz.de|language=en|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * [[University of Otago]] (New Zealand)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.otago.ac.nz/courses/subjects/spte.html|title=Study Sports Technology|website=www.otago.ac.nz|language=en-nz|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * [[Aalborg University]] (Denmark)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.en.aau.dk/education/master/sports-technology|title=Sports Technology|website=www.en.aau.dk|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> * Private University of Applied revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
The '''Tampa 2''' is an [[American football]] defensive scheme popularized by (and thus named after) the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] [[National Football League]] (NFL) team in the mid-1990s–early 2000s. The Tampa 2 is typically employed out of a [[4–3 defense|4–3 defensive alignment]], which consists of four [[Defensive lineman|linemen]], three [[linebacker]]s, two [[Defensive back|cornerbacks]], and two [[Defensive back|safeties]]. The defense is similar to a [[Cover 2]] defense, except the [[middle linebacker]] drops into a deep middle coverage for a [[Cover 3]] when he reads a pass play.<ref name="footballtimes">{{cite news|first=Mohammed|last=Alo|title=Tampa 2 Defense|url=http://www.footballtimes.org/Article.asp?ID=167|work=The Football Times|date=2006-07-04}}</ref>
The term rose to popularity due to the installation and effective execution of this defensive scheme by then-head coach [[Tony Dungy]] and [[defensive coordinator]] [[Monte Kiffin]], and the style helped the Buccaneers win [[Super Bowl XXXVII]].
[[File:Tampa 43 Under Tampa 2 dev.jpg|thumb|right|320x240px|4-3 defense in a Tampa "Under" front, with back 7 falling into Tampa 2 zone coverage. Cornerbacks jam receivers before falling back into their zones. Middle linebacker ensures the deep middle is covered.]]
The roots of the Tampa 2 system actually are in the [[Steel Curtain]] days of Pittsburgh football.<ref name="Jaws">Jaworski, Ron, Cosell, Greg, and Plaut, David ''The Games that Changed the Game'', Ballantine, 2010, Chapter 2.</ref> "My philosophy is really out of the 1975 Pittsburgh Steelers playbook," said Dungy (who played for the Steelers early in his career) during media interviews while at [[Super Bowl XLI]]. "That is why I have to laugh when I hear 'Tampa 2'. [[Chuck Noll]] and [[Bud Carson]]—that is where it came from, I changed very little."<ref>[http://news.steelers.com/article/73586/ Official site of the Pittsburgh Steelers - Article<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070209171311/http://news.steelers.com/article/73586/ |date=2007-02-09 }}</ref> [[Lovie Smith]] mentions having played the system in junior high school during the 1970s, though Carson introduced the idea of moving the middle linebacker into coverage. Carson's system became especially effective with the Steelers' addition of aggressive and athletic middle linebacker [[Jack Lambert (American football)|Jack Lambert]].<ref name="Jaws" /><ref name="ReferenceA">Layden, Tim. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1114104/ "Two Tough"]. 27 Nov 2006. [[Sports Illustrated]]. retrieved July 1, 2013.</ref>
After Dungy became head coach of the [[Indianapolis Colts]] and [[Lovie Smith]] (linebackers coach in Tampa from 1996–2000) became head coach of the [[Chicago Bears]], they installed the Tampa 2 in their respective teams. During the [[2005 NFL season]], the Buccaneers, still under defensive coordinator Kiffin, ranked first in the league in fewest total yards allowed, Smith's Bears ranked number two, and Dungy's Colts ranked eleventh.<ref>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Smith|authorlink=|title='Simple' scheme nets big gains for trio of defenses|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2271514|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2005-12-28|accessdate=2006-01-06 }}</ref> By 2006, the [[Buffalo Bills]], [[Minnesota Vikings]], [[Kansas City Chiefs]], and [[Detroit Lions]] had also adopted the defense. In college football, [[Gene Chizik]] is among the coaches that successfully implemented the Tampa 2.
The scheme is known for its simple format, speed, and the aggressive mentality of its players. Tampa 2 teams are known as gang tacklers with tremendous team speed, and practice to always run to the ball. It also requires a hard hitting secondary to cause turnovers.
==Tampa 2 description== {{Quote|Typically, the [Tampa 2] players don't have the prototypical size of other NFL defenders. Instead, stress is put on speed, smarts and flawless tackling. [...] A quick defensive line is a must, but the middle linebacker position is the straw that stirs the drink.|source=Bryan Mullen, ''[[The Tennessean]]''<ref name="Mullen" />}}
The personnel used in the Tampa 2 are specific in position and required abilities. All positions in this defense place a premium on speed, and often the result is that they are all undersized by league standards. The defensive linemen in this scheme have to be quick and agile enough to create pressure on the quarterback without the aid of a [[Blitz (American football)|blitz]] from either the [[linebackers]] or the secondary, with the defensive tackle in the nose position having above-average tackling skills to help stop runs. [[Warren Sapp]] is often cited as the primary example of a defensive lineman who flourished in this scheme; indeed, he is now reckoned as the prototype three-technique defensive tackle.<ref name=AllDecade>{{cite news | title= A beast on D-line, Warren Sapp became NFL legend in the '00s | url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2010-01-21-all-decade-d-tackles-warren-sapp_N.htm | accessdate=November 20, 2011 | date=January 24, 2010 | work=USA Today}}</ref>
The three linebackers, two cornerbacks and two safeties are responsible for covering the middle of the field. The outside linebackers' general zone is between the cornerbacks, covering the area of the field from the line of scrimmage to 10 yards back. The middle linebacker must have better-than-average speed, and additional skills to be able to read the play and either maintain his central position to help the outside linebackers cover short passes, drop behind the linebackers in coverage and protect the zone of the field behind the outside linebackers from 11-20 yards out, or run up to the line of scrimmage to help assist in stopping the runs. "It takes a special linebacker to do that, a guy with speed," wrote Pete Prisco, senior NFL writer for ''[[CBSSports.com]]''.<ref name="Mullen">{{cite news|first=Bryan|last=Mullen|title=Kiffin's dad enjoys sterling reputation|url=http://tennessean.com/article/20081225/SPORTS0601/812250337/1002/SPORTS|work=The Tennessean|date=2008-12-15}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> The cornerbacks protect the sidelines of the field from the line of scrimmage to anywhere between 15–20 yards out. According to Prisco, they "don't have to be great man-to-man cover players, but they have to be guys who can tackle."<ref name="Mullen" /> Dungy always expected his linebackers and cornerbacks to be above-average tacklers, as they are usually the primary tacklers in the defense.
The two safeties are responsible for covering their respective halves of the field from 20 yards out and more. The safeties in the system are expected to be above-average cover men with the ability to break up passes, but each safety also is expected to have additional specific skills. The strong safeties, while not expected to be great tacklers, are expected to be hard hitters. The hard hitting strong safety protects the middle of the field from being exploited by small, fast receivers, and running backs on [[wheel route]]. The free safety will be called upon to do one of two things in certain situations: either blitz the quarterback, requiring him to have the skills necessary to beat a blocking halfback or fullback, or to assume the coverage zone left by a blitzing cornerback.
The Tampa 2 is particularly effective against teams who are playing from behind, because it limits big plays. It forces offenses to be patient and to settle for short gains and time-consuming drives.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> This may be due to the nature of the "bend-but-don't-break" 2-deep zone coverage scheme and responsibilities safeties play in the Tampa 2.
When executed properly, the Tampa 2 defense is difficult to beat, a reason for its longevity, having seen no fundamental changes since first introduced in 1996. Teams that have been successful against this defense have managed to run the ball up the middle past the defensive tackles, or throw passes in the seams between the outside linebackers and the cornerbacks (often the most effective receiver against a Tampa 2 defense is a [[tight end]], since they often line up against this seam).
Other tactics that have shown to be effective on occasion are misdirection plays that take advantage of the defensive speed and rely on the defense 'over-running' the play (such as the middle linebacker rushing to the line of scrimmage on a play-action pass), or overloading the safeties by having multiple receivers running deep routes, creating more targets in a zone than defenders. Recently, some teams have also been able to exploit the seam between the cornerbacks and the safeties, when the quarterback can throw a pass to a receiver in that seam faster than the safety can rush up to close it and cover the receiver. A recent trend is for teams to send a receiver up the middle, creating a mismatch against the linebacker in coverage. The popularity of the Tampa 2 means that offenses are now finding it effective to exploit the deep middle, where the safeties have to cover the most ground.<ref>Bryant, Howard. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/21/AR2006122101553.html Williams: Offenses Have Uncovered the Cover 2]. 22 Dec 2006. ''[[The Washington Post]]''. retrieved June 24, 2013.</ref>
==Run defense== To defend running plays, the Tampa 2 is a single gap defense where each player is responsible for covering his own gap. The assigned gap changes with game conditions and personnel.
Typically this style of defense utilizes smaller but faster linemen and linebackers with above average speed. Also, the defensive backs must be above average hitters.
The key theme in stopping the run is directing traffic to the weak-side linebacker. It is therefore necessary to have a skilled tackler at the WLB position (e.g., [[Derrick Brooks]], [[Lance Briggs]], [[Sean Lee]]).
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070209171311/http://news.steelers.com/article/73586/ Tony Dungy on the Tampa 2 system] * [https://www.scribd.com/doc/2941589/Cover-2-Dungy-Tampa-Bay-Defense-Install Cover 2 Tony Dungy Install] * Bowen, Matt, [http://www.nationalfootballpost.com/Inside-the-playbook-the-Tampa-2 Inside the Playbook: Tampa 2]
{{Tampa Bay Buccaneers}}
{{American football strategy}}
[[Category:American football strategy]] [[Category:American football terminology]] [[Category:Tampa Bay Buccaneers]]

{{Good article}} {{Use British English|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox University Boat Race | name= 11th Boat Race | winner = Oxford | margin = 9 lengths | winning_time= 21 minutes 36 seconds | overall = 7–4 | umpire =[[Charles Jasper Selwyn|C. J. Selwyn]] | date= {{Start date|1852|4|3|df=y}} | prevseason= [[The Boat Race 1849 (December)|1849 (December)]] | nextseason= [[The Boat Race 1854|1854]] }} The '''11th Boat Race''' took place on the [[River Thames]] on 3 April 1852. Typically held annually, the event is a [[Rowing (sport)#Side by side|side-by-side rowing]] race between crews from the Universities of [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]. Former Cambridge cox [[Thomas Selby Egan]] coached Oxford, the first time that either crew had been trained by a member of the opposing university. The race was won by Oxford, their first Boat Race victory at Easter, who triumphed over Cambridge by nine lengths. ==Background== [[The Boat Race]] is a [[Rowing (sport)#Side by side|side-by-side rowing]] competition between the [[University of Oxford]] (sometimes referred to as the "Dark Blues"){{Cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2003/apr/06/theobserver | work = [[The Observer]] | title = Dark Blues aim to punch above their weight | date = 6 April 2003 | accessdate = 1 September 2014 }} and the [[University of Cambridge]] (sometimes referred to as the "Light Blues"). The race was first held in 1829, and since 1845 has taken place on the {{convert|4.2|mi|km|adj=on}} [[The Championship Course|Championship Course]] on the [[River Thames]] in southwest London.{{Cite web | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/uk/london/10719622/University-Boat-Race-2014-spectators-guide.html | work = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | accessdate = 3 June 2014 | date = 25 March 2014 |title = University Boat Race 2014: spectators' guide | first = Oliver |last =Smith}}{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/the-course | title = The Course| accessdate = 7 November 2014 | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited}} Oxford went into the race as reigning champions, having defeated Cambridge, who were disqualified, in the [[The Boat Race 1849 (December)|previous race]] held in December 1849. Cambridge led overall with seven wins to Oxford's three.{{Cite web | url = http://theboatraces.org/results| publisher= The Boat Race Company Limited | title = Boat Race – Results| accessdate = 26 October 2014}} The universities were unable to agree on a date for race in both 1850 and 1851.MacMichael, pp. 168–171 The challenge to race from Cambridge was received by Oxford in December 1851 and was finally accepted that a race be conducted around Easter the following year.MacMichael, pp. 176–178 Oxford were coached by the former Cambridge [[Coxswain|cox]] [[Thomas Selby Egan]], who had represented the Light Blues in the [[The Boat Race 1836|1836]], [[The Boat Race 1839|1839]] and [[The Boat Race 1840|1840 races]], in protest at the use of [[Waterman (occupation)|watermen]] as Boat Race coaches.{{Cite book | title = Rowing in England: A Social History: the Amateur Debate | first = Eric |last = Halladay | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=9Ee8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA46 | pages = 45–46 | publisher = [[Manchester University Press]] | date = 18 October 1990 | isbn = 978-0719026058}} Oxford had prevented their use since 1841 but Cambridge would not do so until 1873 and were coached by the Thames waterman and world champion sculler [[Robert Coombes|Bob Coombes]].{{Cite web | url = http://www.theboatrace.org/article/introduction/pastresults/1830-1855| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090105235722/http://www.theboatrace.org/article/introduction/pastresults/1830-1855 | publisher = The Boat Race Company Limited | archivedate=5 January 2009 |accessdate= 7 November 2014 |title = 1830–1855}} It was the first time a crew was coached by a member of the other university.MacMichael, p. 181 The umpire for the race was [[Charles Jasper Selwyn]] and the starter was Edward Searle.Burnell p. 49 ==Crews== Three members of the Oxford crew had participated in the previous meeting of the universities in December 1849, Houghton, [[Joseph William Chitty]] and the cox, Cotton. None of the Cambridge crew had Boat Race experience. The Cambridge crew weighed an average of 11 [[Stone (unit)|st]] 8.5 [[Pound (mass)|lb]] (73.5 kg), {{convert|2|lb|kg|1}} per rower more than their opponents. {{Multiple image |align=right |direction=horizontal |width=140 |image1=SirJosephWilliamChitty.jpg |caption1=[[Joseph William Chitty]] rowed at [[Stroke (rowing)|stroke]] for Oxford. |image2=Macnaghten E Vanity Fair 1895-10-31.jpg |caption2=[[Edward Macnaghten, Baron Macnaghten]] occupied the bow seat for Cambridge. }} {| class=wikitable |- ! rowspan="2" |Seat ! colspan="3" |Cambridge
[[File:University of Cambridge coat of arms.svg|30px]] ! colspan="3" |Oxford

Cotton || [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]] || 9 st 2 lb |- !colspan="7"|Source:MacMichael, p. 182
(P) – boat club presidentBurnell pp. 50–51 |} ==Race== [[File:University Boat Race Thames map.svg |thumb|right|[[The Championship Course]] along which the Boat Race is conducted]] Cambridge won the [[coin flipping|toss]] and elected to start on the Surrey side of the river, handing the Middlesex station to Oxford. The race started under Searle's command at 1.45pm with Oxford taking a slight lead. On the approach to [[Hammersmith Bridge]] the gap was closing and Oxford passed through the central arch.MacMichael, p. 183 Cambridge, following Coombe's advice, opted to shoot the bridge towards the Surrey side and in doing so "lost the stream" and allowed Oxford to extend their lead. By [[Barnes Railway Bridge|Barnes Bridge]] the lead was around four lengths,MacMichael, p. 184 and Oxford kept increasing their margin, winning by nine lengths in a time of 21 minutes 36 seconds. It was their second consecutive victory and took the overall record to 7–4 in favour of Cambridge. ==References== '''Footnotes''' {{reflist|30em}} '''Sources''' *{{Cite book | title = One Hundred and Fifty Years of the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race | first = Richard | last = Burnell | authorlink = Dickie Burnell | year=1979| isbn= 978-0-9500638-7-4 | publisher = Precision Press}} *{{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=uJ8CAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22boat%20race%22%20oxford%20cambridge&pg=PA37 | title = The Oxford and Cambridge Boat Races: From A.D. 1829 to 1869| first = William Fisher | last = MacMichael | publisher = Deighton | date = 1870}} ==External links== * [http://theboatraces.org/ Official website] {{The Boat Race}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boat Race 1852)}} [[Category:1852 in sports]] [[Category:The Boat Race]] [[Category:April 1852 sports events]]

{{refimprove|date=August 2017}} In sports that use a clock, '''untimed play''' is play in which the clock does not tick. In some cases, untimed play can occur at the end of a game following the expiration of the clock, and may even be when a score occurs that decides the outcome of the game.
==Gridiron football== In [[gridiron football]], untimed play occurs in the following situations: * [[Extra point]]s following touchdowns are attempted without the clock ticking (except in [[arena football]], which uses a continuously running clock except in the [[One-minute warning|last minute of a half]]) * If the clock expires while a play is in progress, the play continues untimed until the [[dead ball|ball is dead]] * If, at the end of a quarter or a half, a defensive foul occurs, the offense is entitled to an untimed down * Specifically in [[Canadian football]], if the clock expires while the ball is dead, play continues with one untimed down. (This is in contrast to [[American football]], where if the ball is dead and time expires, the half or game immediately ends.) * In leagues that use the [[Kansas playoff]] for [[overtime (sport)|overtime]] (including Canadian, [[college football|college]] and most [[high school football]]), all overtime play is untimed. * In the [[NFL]], [[field goal]] attempts—unless they land in the field of play—are limited to five seconds. Should such a field goal attempt take longer than five seconds to complete, the excess will be untimed.<ref name="nfl-field-goals">{{cite web|last=[[NFL.com]]|title=2017 NFL Rulebook: NFL Football Operations|url=http://operations.nfl.com/the-rules/2017-nfl-rulebook|accessdate=30 July 2017}}</ref> * Also in the [[NFL]], [[Kickoff (gridiron football)|kickoffs]] and [[safety (gridiron football score)|safety kicks]] are untimed unless, and until, the receiving team attempts to return the kick.<ref name="nfl-field-goals"/>
All untimed downs are subject to the [[play clock]] and must commence before it expires, or else a [[delay of game]] penalty is levied.
==Basketball== In [[basketball]], untimed play occurs in the following situations: * [[Free throw]]s are shot without the clock ticking, though in the [[NBA]], there is a 10-second clock to shoot a free throw or else it is forfeited. * At the end of the game, the buzzer automatically ends the game. However, if a player has released the ball from his hands before the buzzer sounds and the ball makes it through the basket, [[Buzzer beater|the score counts]]. * When the ball is put in play by being inbounded, the play is untimed until touched by a player on the court. The player on the court closest to the ball will sometimes take advantage of this by delaying touching the ball for as long as possible by high-bouncing or rolling the ball down the court towards their teammate, buying his or her team a bit more time to shoot before the shot clock or game clock expires. * In [[3x3 (basketball)|3x3]], a formalized version of the 3-on-3 halfcourt game, overtime is untimed. The game ends by rule once either team scores 2 points in overtime, with shots from behind the "three-point" arc worth 2 points and all other shots (whether field goals or free throws) worth 1 point. * [[The Basketball Tournament]], an annual offseason event in the U.S., uses the Elam Ending, an untimed end-of-game procedure, in all games. In the TBT implementation, the game clock proceeds normally until the first dead ball with 4:00 or less remaining in the fourth quarter. At that point, a "target score" is set by adding 7 points to the score of the leading team. The game then resumes, with the shot clock fully operational but the game clock shut off. The first team to reach or exceed the target score wins the game.
==Ice Hockey== In [[ice hockey|hockey]], [[Penalty shot (ice hockey)|penalty shots]] (fairly rare) and [[Overtime (ice hockey)#Shootout|shootouts]] (similar to a penalty shot but more common—taken after regulation time and [[Overtime (ice hockey)|overtime]] end in a tie) are untimed.

Carrier Johnson[http://www.concreteconstruction.net/images/Raker-Beam%20Construction%20Requires%20Rugged%20Steel%20Forms_tcm45-343123.pdf Raker-Beam Construction Requires Rugged Steel Forms] | structural engineer = Martin/Martin | services engineer = M-E Engineers, Inc.[https://web.archive.org/web/20020115231407/http://me-engineers.com/Projects/sports.html M-E Engineers Projects - Sports (archived)] | general_contractor = Blake Construction Co., Inc | former_names = Cox Arena at Aztec Bowl (1997–2009) | tenants = [[San Diego State Aztecs men's basketball|San Diego State Aztecs]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1997–present)
[[San Diego Shockwave]] ([[National Indoor Football League|NIFL]]) (2007) | seating_capacity = 12,414 ([[basketball]])
12,845 (center stage [[concerts]])
12,200 (end stage concerts) }} '''Viejas Arena at Aztec Bowl''' (formerly named '''Cox Arena'''), located on the [[San Diego State University|San Diego State University (SDSU)]] campus in [[San Diego]], [[California]], is the home of the [[San Diego State Aztecs men's basketball]] and women's [[basketball]] teams. Viejas Arena opened its doors to the campus and community in July 1997 and seats 12,414 for [[basketball]][http://goaztecs.cstv.com/facilities/viejas-arena.html Viejas Arena] at goaztecs.cstv.com, URL accessed November 24, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5lX4d7ine?url=http://goaztecs.cstv.com/facilities/viejas-arena.html Archived] 11/24/09 and up to 12,845 for [[concerts]].[http://www.sdsuniverse.info/sdsuniverse/news.aspx?s=70885 SDSU and Viejas Band of Kumeyaay Indians Agree on Arena Naming Rights] at sdsuniverse.info, URL accessed November 24, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5lX4jerHB?url=http://www.sdsuniverse.info/sdsuniverse/news.aspx?s=70885 Archived] 11/24/09 The facility also hosts SDSU's commencement ceremonies. Previously, the Aztecs played at [[Peterson Gym]]nasium also on the SDSU campus.[http://www.eastcountymagazine.org/node/784 The Reno Report: SDSU Basketball Re-enters the Arena] at eastcountymagazine.com, URL accessed November 24, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5lX4xLDRJ?url=http://www.eastcountymagazine.org/node/784 Archived] 11/24/09 However, the men's basketball team played most of their home games at the [[Valley View Casino Center|San Diego Sports Arena]] prior to Viejas Arena's construction. [[Image:Cox Arena interior 2006-02-08.JPG|left|thumb]] Viejas Arena was built on the site of the old [[Aztec Bowl (stadium)|Aztec Bowl]] football stadium (a [[Works Progress Administration]] project) on the SDSU campus, and the university (or its affiliated corporation) still owns the arena. It was originally named Cox Arena after [[Cox Communications]], which owns one of the local [[cable television]] systems in the greater San Diego regional area, and which [[naming rights|paid fees]] to become the arena's corporate sponsor. The arena was renamed to Viejas Arena under a 10-year naming rights agreement announced March 17, 2009. The naming rights agreement with the [[Viejas Band of Kumeyaay Indians]] went into effect July 1 and will pay the university about $6 million over the next 10 years.http://www.cbs8.com/Global/story.asp?S=10023979&nav=menu1607_2_2 On October 29, 2015, the basketball court was named Steve Fisher Court after men's basketball head coach [[Steve Fisher]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sports/aztecs/sdut-viejas-steve-fisher-court-sdsu-2015oct29-story.html|title=Viejas floor named Steve Fisher Court|last=Union-Tribune|first=San Diego|newspaper=sandiegouniontribune.com|access-date=2016-11-08}} Viejas Arena hosted the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|men's NCAA basketball tournament]] first and second rounds in 2001, 2006, 2014, and 2018. In the 2006 tourney, the first-round games were delayed and the building evacuated due to a bomb-sniffing dog picking up scents of a potentially dangerous substance. These fears were unfounded, however, and play went on as scheduled.[http://sports.espn.go.com/travel/passport/event?uid=14914&eid=13445 (10) Alabama 90, (7) Marquette 85] at sports.espn.go.com, URL accessed November 24, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5lX5MPeMZ?url=http://sports.espn.go.com/travel/passport/event?uid=14914 Archived] 11/24/09 Because of its status as SDSU's home court, the Aztecs were not allowed to open the tournament at home (under "pod system" rules).[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/4529464 It's simple: The pod system is a failure] at nbcsports.msnbc.com, URL accessed November 24, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5lX5Z9PSE?url=http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/4529464 Archived] 11/24/09 Viejas Arena has also hosted [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]]'s [[Bash at the Beach (1998)|Bash at the Beach]] in 1998 and some episodes of WCW Monday Nitro. In 2007, the arena was the home of the [[San Diego Shockwave]] [[indoor American football|indoor football]] team for one season.[http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/united_states/california.shtml Stadiums in the United States] at worldstadiums.com, URL accessed November 24, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5lX5xwb3q?url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/united_states/california.shtml Archived] 11/24/09 Viejas Arena is also used as a large concert venue where major acts perform, including [[Britney Spears]], [[Blink-182]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Janet Jackson]], [[A Day To Remember]], [[Linkin Park]], [[Metallica]], [[Van Halen]], [[Green Day]], [[Gorillaz]], [[Rise Against]], [[Tool (band)|Tool]], [[Daniel Taylor (countertenor)|Daniel Taylor]], [[Lady Gaga]], [[One Direction]], [[Fleetwood Mac]], and [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]]. The arena is often used as an alternative to the much larger [[Valley View Casino Center]] (the former Sports Arena) across town. The arena was also the host of filming [[Megadeth]]'s live DVD ''[[Blood in the Water: Live in San Diego]]''. Lady Gaga performed at Viejas Arena on her [[artRAVE: The ARTPOP Ball Tour]], on June 2, 2014. The arena hosted [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|TNA Wrestling]]'s [[TNA Bound For Glory|Bound For Glory]] 2013 pay-per-view event on October 20, 2013. ==See also== * [[San Diego State Aztecs]] * [[Aztec Bowl (stadium)|Aztec Bowl]] * [[Viejas Casino]] * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.viejasarena.com/ Viejas Arena] - official page * [http://www.goaztecs.com/facilities/sdsu-trads-cox.html Page on goaztecs.com] {{s-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{Succession box | title = Host of [[TNA Bound for Glory|Bound for Glory]] | years = [[Bound for Glory (2013)|2013]] | before = [[Grand Canyon University Arena]] | after = TBD }} {{end}} {{San Diego State Aztecs men's basketball navbox}} {{Mountain West Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Live Nation}} {{Bound for Glory venues}} {{coord|32|46|25.5|N|117|4|28.5|W|region:US-CA_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in California]] [[Category:Sports venues in San Diego]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:San Diego State Aztecs basketball venues]] [[Category:Professional wrestling venues in California]] [[Category:Music venues in California]] [[Category:1997 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1997]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in California]]
